citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
* The following medications used to treat the dogs at the facility have gone past their labeled expiration dates. The
recorded expiration date on one 100 ml bottle of Oxytocin was 10/13. The recorded expiration date on one 16 fluid oz
bottle of Pyrantel Pamote Suspension was 07/06/22. There was one container of Ponazuril and one container on Amforal
both had an expiration date of 12/31/22. These medications are intermingled with other products that are currently being
used at the facility and are therefore ready for use. The usage of expired medical materials such as drugs, fluids, or
sutures on regulated animals is not considered to be an acceptable veterinary practice and does not constitute adequate
veterinary care. The effectiveness of the dosage level and expected results when expired drugs are administrated to
animals could be drastically changed or may not work as anticipated. The expected results cannot be guaranteed and the
animals may experience pain, distress due to mistreatment, unrelieved symptoms or unexpected side effects. Failure to
properly label medications or other medical products as being expired and storing them with unexpired medical materials
could lead to the unintentional use on regulated animals. The licensee must either dispose of all such expired medical
drugs and materials or segregate them in an appropriately labeled, physically separate location from non-expired medical
drugs and materials. Correct by 3/28/23.

* An estimated two by four inch area of missing wall board was observed on the outside wall. Two dogs are in contact
with the affected surface area located on the outside wall of sheltered housing. Surfaces not maintained on a regular
basis cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized. The missing surface area could harbor disease causing agents which
affects the health and well-being of the dogs. The licensee must ensure all surfaces are being maintained on a regular
basis. Surfaces that cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized, must be replaced when worn or soiled or altered in a
manner that allows for cleaning and sanitation to occur. Correct by 4/14/23.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
End Section

narrative:
2.40(a) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
*   The following medications used to treat the dogs at the facility have gone past their labeled expiration dates.  The 
recorded expiration date on one 100 ml bottle of Oxytocin was 10/13.  The recorded expiration date on one 16 fluid oz 
bottle of Pyrantel Pamote Suspension was 07/06/22.  There was one container of Ponazuril and one container on Amforal 
both had an expiration date of 12/31/22.  These medications are intermingled with other products that are currently being 
used at the facility and are therefore ready for use. The usage of expired medical materials such as drugs, fluids, or 
sutures on regulated animals is not considered to be an acceptable veterinary practice and does not constitute adequate 
veterinary care. The effectiveness of the dosage level and expected results when expired drugs are administrated to 
animals could be drastically changed or may not work as anticipated. The expected results cannot be guaranteed and the 
animals may experience pain, distress due to mistreatment, unrelieved symptoms or unexpected side effects.  Failure to 
properly label medications or other medical products as being expired and storing them with unexpired medical materials 
could lead to the unintentional use on regulated animals.   The licensee must either dispose of all such expired medical 
drugs and materials or segregate them in an appropriately labeled, physically separate location from non-expired medical 
drugs and materials.  Correct by 3/28/23. 
3.1(c)(2) 
   
Housing facilities, general.

*  An estimated two by four inch area of missing wall board was observed on the outside wall.  Two dogs are in contact 
with the affected surface area located on the outside wall of sheltered housing.  Surfaces not maintained on a regular 
basis cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized.  The missing surface area could harbor disease causing agents which 
affects the health and well-being of the dogs.  The licensee must ensure all surfaces are being maintained on a regular 
basis.  Surfaces that cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized, must be replaced when worn or soiled or altered in a 
manner that allows for cleaning and sanitation to occur.  Correct by 4/14/23. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
End Section
